courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: College Assembly
courses.description: This activity aims to enhance the general knowledge of students in fields outside of their major studies. Topics presented at the Assemblies include culture, science, art and social issues. Six to eight large-scale assemblies attended by more than 1300 students, held in Sir Run Run Shaw Hall and a number of smaller assemblies, held on the College and other University campus, are organised each year for students’ selection. Each assembly consist of topical discussion, College session, Student Union session, and award presentation to outstanding staff and students.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Understand the moral ethics associated with the College motto "ming de xin min".
理解與書院校訓「明德新民」的道德理想
Formulate personal set of positive attitudes and values.
建立個人積極的人生態度及價值
Recognize the common concerns of contemporary physical and social environment.
關注當代人類共同面對的重大議題
Develop cohesion and sense of belonging to United College.
發展對母校的凝聚力和歸屬感
Increase interests and improve life style.
拓展興趣及提升生活品味
Demonstrate intercultural sensitivity and appreciate different culture.
具有跨文化觸覺，能欣賞不同文化
courses.course_syllabus:
Guests from various organizations and fields are invited to give speeches at College Assemblies; other formats like group discussion and performance may be arranged as well. A wide range of themes including culture, art, science, social affairs, as well as those for enhancing personal growth of students will be arranged for our College Assemblies.
每次書院聚會設專題探討，邀請各界專家、學者作嘉賓，以增進同學對文化、藝術、科學及社會問題之認識，及在個人成長方面有所提升。採用之形式包括講座、討論、表演等。
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Will be presented at Meetings of “Working Group on College Assemblies” and “Committee on General Education” of the College.
同學的意見和評核將在《書院聚會工作小組》及書院《通識教育委員會》會議上檢視

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: University Life and Learning
courses.description: This course is designed to provide basic preparation for studying in the university. Topics include the aims of a university, the purposes of university education, campus life and the art of thinking - an introduction to the basic concepts, principles and methods of logical thinking, the rules of rational discourse and of scientific enquiry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For United College Year 1 Students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. 建立與書院校訓一致的人生態度及價值觀；
2. 關注當代人類共同面對的重大議題；
3. 以終身學習的態度去拓展興趣，及提升生活品味；
4. 掌握獨立思考和創新思維的能力；
5. 提升包容和欣賞跨文化的能力。
courses.course_syllabus:
課題 內容
基本能力 如何管理您的生活、個人誠信、運動與健康、圖書館資源\*
適應轉變 大學生活、心理健康、學習方法、性別認知
開闊視野 通識教育、舞台劇欣賞、歷史今昔
關心社會 大數據世代
書院關係 聯合書院的邁進

內容每年不同，由書院通識教育委員會於五月議訂下一學年的題目及講者。每年最少有兩個題目的變動，主要是因應世界和香港社會的轉變。

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Bacchus: Exploring Grape Wine

schedule.class_attributes: Can, change to Eng if needed
Can, change to Eng if needed

courses.description:
Wine weaves in with human history from its very beginnings and developed into one of the foremost products of civilization. Great wines have their roots in the customs, traditions and history of their home ground. Celebration of vine and wine is often associated with the legend and worship of Bacchus, the wine God. Similarly, the origins of fermenting and drinking wine in China go far back in time. Tu Kang 杜康is a household name. It is no doubt that wine occupies an important place in the culture and life of the Chinese people.

This course leads students on a cultural journey on wine around the world. It introduces to students a historical perspective on wine and its role in society. In addition, it provides students with basic knowledge on wine appreciation, and the relationship among wine, food and culture. Students can develop the skill to taste wines of common production regions and grape varieties. They can develop a positive understanding on various aspects of life through appreciation of wine culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For United College Year 2 and Year 3 students only.
Not for HTMG students.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will have acquired basic knowledge on appreciation, selection, serving, and tasting of wines. In addition, students should be able to:

1. understand the relationship of social, historical and cultural factors that interact with wines, and health and social issues associated with alcoholism.
2. use basic terminology to describe the sensory properties of wines and evaluate wines by tasting
3. link cuisine art and lifestyle, and understand the concepts of wine and food matching.
4. assess wines for basic attributes, varietal character, terroir, and basic wine styles
5. discuss tradition, historical, and geographical characteristics and diversity of wines of the Old World and New World countries, and various country systems for classification of wines.

Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:

1. describe connections and integrate knowledge across fields;
2. demonstrate the ability to think independently and innovatively;
3. cultivate comprehensive views to appreciate different cultures; and
4. develop leadership skills, and be able to collaborate and communicate effectively in teamwork.
courses.course_syllabus:
The topics include cultural history of wine and its role in society; descriptions of major wine types, wine-producing regions, grape varieties, and vintages; explanations of label terminology and wine production methods; techniques for opening and serving wine; and an introduction to sensory training and comparative tasting methods.

1. The Ways of Wine and Society
• History of wines and different cultural tastes throughout the civilization evolution
• Sensory evaluation of wines – the science and practice of wine tasting, assessment techniques, the senses and how they work
• Wines and cuisine – principles of wine and food matching
• The rituals of wine – factors governing selection, storage and serving of wines

2. Vinification and Viticulture
• The vine species and dominant international vs. regional grape varietals
• Terroir (soil, temperature, rainfall, slopes), yield and quality of wines
• In the vineyard and the winegrower’s year
• The art of the winemakers – fermentation, and white and red wine making processes

3. Wines and Travel - The World of Wines
• The vine conquers the world – regions where Vitis Vinifera has developed are also regions where various civilizations reached peak of development
• New World versus Old World competition – stress on varietal as opposed to geographical, distinctions, identities, and labeling
• Leading wine production countries – their history, local culture, geographic location, famous wine regions and wine labeling laws (e.g. Appellation d'origine contrôlée (AOC) in France and Denominazione di Origine Controllata (DOC) in Italy)

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Leadership in Practice
courses.description: It has been well established that experiential training is an excellent means of developing leadership, confidence, team spirit and other qualities of character. For many years the development of such qualities has been recognized as being of high importance by the senior management of the academic, non-government and commercial organizations. Leadership is best learned by doing. This course will explore and examine leadership theory and practice through experiential learning in the outdoor and a different setting rather than studying mainly in a classroom. It provides students with a structured, supervised programme of participation in the practice of leadership and teambuilding. The goal of this course is to help students acquire practical skills and judgment to develop their leadership qualities. On completion of this course, students will be able to identify and achieve their goals at a comparatively earlier stage in life.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For United College Year 2 and Year 3 students only.
courses.course_syllabus:
This subject aims to bring out students’ firm understanding of the vital attributes of leadership skills for meeting the training needs of today’s young people. It places students in a simulated situation and coaches them to be responsible for dealing with problems, challenges and routine skills when training students to be practical, sensible and helpful in our society. The theory of outdoor experiential training for leadership and team building is that leadership skills can be honed and team spirit developed by taking students into the great outdoors. This concept features both physical and mental exercises.

Key theories about leadership will be introduced with their practical applications for leadership including the follows:
1. Defining leadership
2. Leadership and management
3. Nature of leadership and leadership styles
4. Action-centred leadership
5. Leadership checklist
6. Time management for leaders
7. Motivation for leaders
8. Creativity at work
9. Leadership tasks

The course includes a mixture of lectures, interactive tutorial, group discussion and challenge course which is specially designed to enhance personal development and team spirit in the sense of problem solving, caring colleagues and coping with the difficulties through participating in a series of challenging and exciting outdoor activities in an energetic and fun-filled atmosphere.

Students will be divided into small groups. Through job rotation, each student has opportunity to take a leading position to complete a leadership task. The training involves facilitators leading the students through activities, encouraging them to reflect on experiences and helping them to transfer the knowledge and skills learned to a working context. It focuses on enhancing self-awareness, changing attitudes, building teams and improving inter-personal skills.

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Design Thinking Approach to Innovation
courses.description:
The course aims to develop “T-shaped” characters who can develop the depth of expertise in a single field (one’s major as represented by the vertical bar of the T) while acquiring the ability to communicate and collaborate with others from different disciplines (the horizontal bar of the T) to address challenges. The ability to connect horizontally is “design thinking”. Individuals equipped with the ability to think as a designer will be able to innovate, tackle complex problems and manage changes in real life situations.

With “design thinking” or by “thinking as a designer”, students can begin to understand how our world has come to its current form through intended and unintended design. Knowing that the only thing that is not designed, is nature, humans need to learn where to draw the line. By acquiring a designer’s mindset in looking at the world, each person can do one’s part to be a responsible and conscious prosumer of design. This includes utilizing eco-friendly artifacts and designing one’s learning, career and life experience on this planet in a responsible way.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For United College year 2 or year 3 students.
Not for IBBA major students.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Experience Economy, Network Society, and Design Thinking
(a) Trace the rise of the experience economy and network society
(b) Integrate user experience (UX), technology platform (TP), and business model (BM) to foster innovation
(c) Understand the relationship between creativity, design and innovation
(d) Facilitate the design process through divergent and convergent thinking methods and techniques in a multidisciplinary team context
(e) Manage team formation and project implementation with digital tools

2. Managing the Design Process
(a) Gain deep insights into the ecosystem dynamics formed by the various social actors as they respond to external forces and trends
(b) Recognize the importance of cultural identity and branding in the design process
(c) Use brainstorming and visualization as a means to frame and solve problems
(d) Storyboarding role playing the user journey
(e) Build and test out prototypes to expedite the learning process

3. Technology Platform and Business Model for Sustainable Innovation
(a) The cloud and big data environment
(b) Platforms and frameworks for industry disruption and transformation
(c) Using technology (including crowd sourcing and open-innovation resources) to gain competitive and process advantages
(d) Business model mapping for product-market fit
(e) Validate user and customer adoption with Kickstarter, user testing, social media, and field observation

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Social Service: Participation and Reflection
courses.description: The objective of this course is to foster students to become positive and responsible citizens through participating in community social service. Based on the principles of service-learning and theories of experiential learning, the course assists students to consolidate their prior and on-going community service experiences. Through self reflection, small group discussion, community agency visits and project presentation, students will be able to understand the needs of vulnerable groups, aware of human issues related to social justice and develop positive attitude to community social service. The purpose of this course is to facilitate students’ self development and develop a long-term interest in serving the community and populations in need.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For United College students to take in their second year and third year of study only.
Social Work major students cannot take the course to fulfill General Education requirements.
courses.course_syllabus:
The major concepts and topics to be covered in this course are:

I. Theory and Practice of Service-Learning
i. Theoretical roots of service-learning
ii. Basics and principles of service-learning
iii. Positive and best practices in service-learning

II. Perspectives on Personal Development
i. A humanistic approach to personal growth
ii. Choice theory approach to personal growth
iii. Multiple intelligences and multiple learning styles

III. Principles of Experiential and Reflective Learning
i. Three models of the experiential learning process
ii. Kolb’s experiential learning cycle
iii. Practice of reflective learning

IV. Importance of Civic Responsibilities
i. Volunteerism
ii. Principles of social justice
Social Entrepreneurship

I. Introduction, course requirements and conceptualization
II. Understanding the socially disadvantaged, understanding social enterprise in Hong Kong
III. Principles and skills in visit and interview

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Public Affairs: Participation and Reflection
courses.description: This course aims to foster students’ sense of citizenship and leadership by enhancing their ability to understand and analyse political and social problems. It is not confined to the technical training of political and policy analysts, but broadened to the liberal education of citizens who have the knowledge, attitudes and competence to participate in public affairs. The purpose of the course is to raise the awareness of students towards social issues, nurture their ability to identify and analyse the pivotal aspects of the issues, and most importantly, encourage the students to form their own opinions and to suggest solutions. In line with this purpose, the course is issue-oriented, with controversial issues cutting across the discussions and reflections. Apart from classroom teaching and discussion, there will also be field trips to government agencies as well as non-government organizations, in which students will have opportunities to directly exchange ideas and opinions with government officials, community leaders and ordinary people.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For United College students to take in their second or third year of study.
Government and Public Administration major students cannot take this course to fulfill General Education requirements.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course will furnish the students with the following capacities and skills:

1. Throughout the course the students are expected to master the basic concepts in political analysis and be able to apply them to analyse real-world problems. More specifically, the students are expected to develop some basic knowledge as to the different features of civil society, social movement and governance.
2. By taking this course, the students are expected to be familiar with a wide range of practical problems besting the ordinary citizens in Hong Kong and the Mainland China. The students are encouraged to consider and observe the ways in which civil society can help to tackle and resolve these problems, and whether too much hope is placed on civil society.
3. In recent years the places like Hong Kong, Mainland China and Asia in general has been marked by the rise of social movements and new social movements. By taking this course, the students are expected to develop the skills to analyse the rationale behind the social movements and their impact on governance. Perhaps more importantly, the students are expected to have the opportunity and ability to reflect on the ‘optimal’ relationships between government, private corporations and the social activists of a new generation.
4. This course is intended to develop the students into active and considerate citizens. In order to become good citizens, they must master generic skills in terms of articulating and communicating complicated ideas and analytical results effectively in both verbal and written formats. These skills are unlikely to emerge automatically. They have to be deliberately nurtured. In this course, through face-to-face interaction with social participants, and a round of presentation and discussion exercises, the students are offered a well-organised setting where their analytical and communicating skills can burgeon.

Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:

1. understand the College motto and develop positive attitudes and values;
2. recognize the common concerns of the contemporary world;
3. demonstrate social enterprisingness in protecting the environment and serving the community; and
4. demonstrate the ability to think independently and innovatively.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture Plan

Week One (2 Hours). Civil Society and the State

Theme: This lecture introduces the concepts of the state and civil society. It studies the challenges that the contemporary governments encounter in doing public governance from a state-society interaction perspective.

Week Two (2 Hours). Social Movement

Theme: This topic aims at providing a general picture of the development, processes and characteristics of traditional and new social movements, particularly in relation to the theoretical framework of state-civil society relations discussed in previous topic.

Week Three/Four (total 4 Hours). Guest speaker’s session/fieldtrip

Week Five/Six/Seven (total 5 Hours). Group presentation and discussion

List of organizations
1. Politics/ Think tank
2. New media
3. Urbanism/ Urban politics
4. Art and Culture
5. Green
6. Community

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Social Innovation: Social Enterprises and Demand
courses.description: This course is designed to equip students with a basic understanding of social enterpreneurship through whole experience learning, not just the actual academics. Social entrepreneurship education is about collaboration, multi-disciplinary learning, learning-by-doing, problem-solving, and tackling the “real” problems. Through self-reflection, small group discussion, experiential learning by participating in social enterprise workshops and project presentations, students will be able to understand more the needs of underprivileged groups and the challenges of social enterprises. The purpose of this course is to facilitate students to learn more about the societal needs of the community and develop an innovative mindset to solve social issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Year 2 or above United College students only.
courses.course_attributes:
Experiential Learning Course
Service Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, student should be able to:

1. Get a basic understanding about the nature and types of social enterprises

2. Identify the societal needs of underprivileged groups in Hong Kong

3. Understand the strategic positions of social enterprises in societal betterment

4. Understand the advantages of social enterprises in response to societal needs

5. Plan to solve a real challenge that social enterprise is facing

Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:

1. Understand the College motto and develop positive attitudes and values

2. Recognize the common concerns of contemporary world

3. Demonstrate social enterprisingness in protecting the environment and serving the community

4. Develop life-long learning habits for expanding interest and improving life-style

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Social Service in action: Participation and Reflection
courses.description:
The objective of this course is to foster students to become positive and responsible citizens through participating in service learning activity to community. Based on the principles of service-learning, social enterprisingness, and theories of experiential learning, the students are required to plan and implement a series of direct services, or other modes of service-learning for selected socially disadvantaged groups. Through self-reflection, small group discussion, and project presentation, students will be able to understand the needs of vulnerable groups, develop positive attitude to service learning and community social services.

The purpose of this course is to facilitate students’ self-development and long-term interest in caring of the community for sustainable development.

SDG#11: Sustainable Cities and Communities
Social service addresses the needs of vulnerable or disadvantaged groups within our community. By providing support and resources, our service learning activities help to develop sustainable supporting networks and ensure all members of the community have access to it.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Year 2-3 United College students only.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-SE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
Service Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Understand the theory and practice of service-learning and social enterprise

2. Integrate community service or other service-learning modes with the related principles

3. Relate their service-learning experience with the concepts of civic responsibility and sustainable development (SDG#11)

4. Critically appraise their personal development in relation to their service-learning experience

5. Develop an awareness towards populations in need and identify ways to serve them

6. Initiate long-term interest to serve the community and society

7. Practice constant self-reflection in order to achieve self-discovery and self-expression

Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:

1. Understand the College motto and develop positive attitudes and values

2. Recognise the common concerns of the contemporary world

3. Demonstrate social enterprise in protecting the environment and serving the community

4. Develop life-long learning habits for expanding interest and improving life-style

SDG#11: Sustainable Cities and Communities:

1. Engage with local communities and contribute to initiatives that promote sustainable community development
courses.course_syllabus:
Service-Learning

The major contents to be covered in this course are:

Interactive Lectures

- Conceptualisation: Volunteerism vs Service-Learning

- Previous Outstanding Service-Learning project ideas

- Spotting out the vulnerable in the society

- Imaging an ideal community

- Rationale, principles and 5 steps model of Design Thinking; N3C Framework: Needs, Capacity, Character, Circumstances

- Preparation for Empathy and communication skills with target; tools of field observation, outreaching tactics, interview and contingency skills

Service Delivery

- Observe potential target groups and to immerse their daily lives

- Interview potential target and understand the pain points and needs (Empathise)

- Problem definition (Define) and brainstorm a further action idea (Ideate)

- Action for Service

Presentation and Reflection

- Group presentation on service delivered and things learnt

- Personal reflection on personal growth and care for the society

1. Get a basic understanding about the nature and types of social enterprises

2. Identify the societal needs of underprivileged groups in Hong Kong

3. Understand the strategic positions of social enterprises in social betterment

4. Understand the advantages of social enterprises in response to social needs

5. Plan to solve a real challenge that social enterprise is facing

Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:

1. Understand the College motto and develop positive attitudes and values

2. Recognize the common concerns of contemporary world

3. Understand the meaning of service-learning and reflect on the experience learnt through different types of community service

4. Develop life-long learning habits for expanding interest and improving life-style

SDG#8: Decent Work and Economic Growth:

1. Understand how social enterprises maintain sustainable economic growth by business operations

2. Recognize social enterprises’ practices to provide decent work

SDG#10: Reduced Inequalities:

1. Recognize social enterprises or other business practices to embrace social inclusion and reduce inequalities

SDG#11: Sustainable Cities and Communities:

1. Engage with local communities and contribute to initiatives that promote sustainable community development
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture themes

1. What is Social Innovation / Social Enterprise? Social Enterprises in Hong Kong

2. Real cases sharing by Social Enterprises in understanding their Missions and Challenges

3. Social Enterprise Workshops - social enterprise human libraries

4. Resourcefulness - Through circle of influence and multi-disciplinary collaborations (e.g. social capital, CSR,CSV)

5. Innovation mindset - Turning problems into innovative ideas and practice the ideas via service learning activities

6. Final Presentation and Evaluation - present an idea how to support a designed social enterprise from a youth perspective

\*These topics aim to provide a comprehensive understanding of social enterprises, learn from real-world practices, and encourage innovative thinking and collaboration to fulfill social needs.

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Leadership in Practice: Service
courses.description:
This course will explore and examine leadership theory and practice through experiential learning in outdoor settings, rather than being limited to classroom learning. Students will apply theoretical concepts to real-world situations through practice, enhancing their understanding of leadership principles. The course also includes elements of service learning, such as activities related to environmental protection like trail restoration, providing students with practical team leadership and hands-on experience that positively impacts the community and the environment (SDG #15 Life on Land).

Participating in trail restoration not only fosters teamwork and communication but also cultivates a sense of responsibility toward environmental protection. Students will learn how to navigate challenges, communicate effectively, and motivate their peers as they work toward a common goal. Additionally, this experience will enable students to reflect on their own leadership styles and adapt them to different contexts, further strengthening their ability to lead diverse teams.

Moreover, by sharing this knowledge and experience to the public, students will help cultivate a broader culture of environmental awareness and community involvement. They will prepare workshops to share insights gained from service-learning activities, such as trail restoration. These workshops may include hands-on demonstrations, discussions on sustainable practices, and the importance of environmental protection. By collaborating NGOs, students will also host clean-up trail workshops, tree-planting activities, or exhibitions, which not only educate the public but also actively involve them in environmental action. These service learning activities will inspire a collective commitment to sustainability and social responsibility , creating lasting environmental awareness within the community.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Year 2-3 United College students only.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-SE #15 Life On Land
Experiential Learning Course
Service Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successfully completing this course, students will be able to:

1. Execute the five main leadership functions which required by Action-centered Leadership

2. Coordinate members to work together as an effective team

3. Apply problem solving strategies in tackling the assigned leadership task

4. Exhibit skills in communication in maintaining the morale of the team

5. Construct their own conception of leadership.

Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:

1. Describe connections and integrate knowledge across fields

2. Understand the meaning of service-learning and reflect on the experience learnt through different types of community service

3. Foster comprehensive awareness in the sustainable development goals

4. Develop leadership skills, and be able to collaborate and communicate effectively in teamwork

5. Identify and apply sustainable development tools and strategies to address social problems to achieve SDG#15
courses.course_syllabus:
This subject aims to bring out students’ firm understanding of the vital attributes of leadership skills for meeting the training needs of today’s young people. It places students in a simulated situation and coaches them to be responsible for dealing with problems, challenges and routine skills when training students to be practical, sensible and helpful in our society. The theory of outdoor experiential training for leadership and team building is that leadership skills can be honed and team spirit developed by taking students into the great outdoors. This concept features both physical and mental exercises.

Key theories about leadership will be introduced with their practical applications for leadership including the follows:

1. Defining leadership

2. Leadership and management

3. Nature of leadership and leadership styles

4. Action-centred leadership

5. Leadership checklist

6. Time management for leaders

7. Motivation for leaders

8. Creativity at work

9. Leadership tasks

| Week | Items | Objective |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Overview Knowing your team Lecture (1): Defining Leadership * Nature of Leadership & Leadership Styles * Action Centred Leadership * Introducing the Leader-Observer-Member system *Trial Task: Finding Values* -Introducing the basic knowledge of Services Learning | This lecture introduces leadership fundamentals, focusing on team dynamics, leadership styles, and the Action Centred Leadership model. It also covers the Leader-Observer-Member system and the basics of service learning, helping students understand core values and apply leadership principles in service learning activities. |
| 2 | Recap of Lecture One Lecture (2): Leader’s Checklist & Observer’s Duties Lecture (3): Use of Time for Leaders in Service Learning Activities Task (1a): Keylock Lecture (4): Motivation for Leaders in Service Task Task (1b): Jigsaw Puzzles | The lecture is to equip students with essential tasks and outline leader and observer roles, effective time management in service learning, and develop problem-solving skills through various tasks. |
| 3 (1-night & 2day camp) | Assembly at 1430 at PSW, boat to WSS Recap of Lecture Two / Group Photos Task (2): Site Survey Break Lecture (5): Briefing on Environmental Protection and trail restoration Task (3): Radio Advertisement Lecture (6): Servant Leadership in trail restoration Dinner Task (4): Creative CEO: Environmental Protection Education to the public Task (5): Night Activity Skill input on Services Project: trail restoration | The 1-night & 2-day camp is to educate students on environmental protection and trail restoration through hands-on service-learning activities, lectures, and creative tasks. It aims to develop leadership skills, promote teamwork, and enhance understanding of environmental issues, culminating in practical applications and public education efforts. |
| 3 (1-night & 2-day camp) | Task (6): Leaders assembly at 0715 Task (7): Morning Activity Task (8a): Pioneering Task Task (8b): Morning Dip and Rafting Lunch Service Project Briefing Service Project: Trail Maintenance Debriefing |
| 4 | Recap of 1-night 2-day camp Task (9): Environmental Protection Education to the public: workshops and activities plan Round up | The trail workshops and tree-planting activities in collaboration with the Scout Association is to promote environmental stewardship and conservation. These activities aim to educate students on sustainable practices, enhance their understanding of ecosystem restoration, and foster a sense of community and teamwork through hands-on involvement in preserving natural habitats. |
| 5 | Task (10): Host trail workshops, tree-planting activities in collaboration with Scout Association |
| 6 | Submitting reflection papers Recap of trail workshops, tree-planting activities Post Service Presentation and Sharing Certificate Presentation Course Evaluation - Peer Evaluation - LTI Evaluation - CU Evaluation (Teaching Team leaves) End of Course | Sharing the experiences and outcomes of the service activities fosters a sense of accomplishment, encourage learning from the experiences, and share insights and impacts with peers, promoting continuous improvement and community engagement. |

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Design Thinking: Action for Service
courses.description:
This course aims to cultivate students' "T-shaped" learning qualities, enabling them to expand their skills within their major while also communicating and collaborating with individuals from different disciplines.

Integrating design thinking into a service learning course enhances students' ability to develop creative and effective solutions to community challenges. The process begins with empathy, where students understand community needs through interviews and observations. They then define the problem based on their findings. Implementation involves putting the viable solution into action, requiring collaboration and project management. Throughout the process, reflection is encouraged to help students understand the impact of their work and foster personal growth. This course not only enhances problem-solving skills but also ensures that solutions are tailored to meet real community needs, promoting meaningful and sustainable impact. Students will be linked with various NGOs and social enterprises to design solutions that assist beneficiaries. For example, students will participate in Elderly-oriented Home Transformation Service and apply design thinking knowledge to assist the elderly in redesigning their homes and enhancing the living quality of the elderly.

Various project groups within the course focuses on different sustainable development goals, such as no poverty (SDG#1), elderly needs, healthy lives and well-being (SDG#3). Through service-learning activities, students and community members are expected to enhance their cohesiveness and deepen their concerns for the local community (SDG＃11).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Year 2-3 United College students only.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-SE #1 No Poverty
SDG-SE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-SE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
Service Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of the module, students are expected to be able to:

1. Understand the background that gives rise to the experience economy, network society, and design thinking movement

2. Understand what "design thinking" or "thinking as a designer" means and be able to participate in a design process

3. Utilize role playing, prototyping and visualization aids to frame and solve problems in a group settings

4. Apply design thinking in service-learning activities, and become a modern day "educated person".

Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:

1. Describe connections and integrate knowledge across fields

2. Understand the meaning of service-learning and reflect on the experience learnt through different types of community service

3. Foster comprehensive awareness in the sustainable development goals

4. Develop leadership skills, and be able to collaborate and communicate effectively in teamwork

5. Identify and apply sustainable development tools and strategies to address social problems in facilitating Sustainable Development Goals (SDG # 1,3, 11)
courses.course_syllabus:
* *1. Knowledge to understand**
a. Principles of Design Thinking as a creative problem-solving approach
b. Social innovation for people, planet, prosperity
c. Mindset for design thinking, creativity, innovation, strategy
d. Fundamental for user experience/ customer journey design
e. Training as educated global citizens with United Nations -Sustainable development goals (SDG#1, #3 #11)

* *2. Tools in practices**

a. Experiencing the use of Empathy Map
b. Practicing of “chunking” languages and questioning framework
c. Participating in the exercise of Perceptual Position and its application
d. Brainstorming to generate ideas and implementing structured process to get insights and bring innovation

* *3. Project for mastery**
a. Studying cases of impactful social innovation
b. Co-creating valuable experiences together with community partners
c. Developing project proposal with community-driven design initiative
d. Strengthening the ability by applying the learnings in different context and in group setting

This resource outlines the principles of design thinking specifically tailored for social innovation, offering case studies and methodologies.
2. “Design Kit: The Human-Centered Design Toolkit” by IDEO<https://www.ideo.com/journal/design-kit-the-human-centered-design-toolkit>
This toolkit provides practical methods and insights for applying human-centered design principles to social innovation projects. Materials for case studies.
3. Prahalad, Coimbatore K., and Venkatram Ramaswamy. "The new frontier of experience innovation." *MIT Sloan management review* 44.4 (2003).

Chapter 7:Enhancing Public Innovation through Collaboration, Leadership (p145-p165)This elaborates the importance of collaboration and essentials for future leadership.

This is the official UN document outlining the 17 SDGs and their targets. It provides a comprehensive framework for global sustainable development. This Agenda is a plan of action for people, planet and prosperity.

"SDG Compass The guide for business action on the SDGs"by GRI, the UN Global Compact and the World Business Council for Sustainable Development [(WBCSD)](https://sdgs.un.org/sites/default/files/publications/21252030%20Agenda%20for%20Sustainable%20Development%20web.pdf)<https://d306pr3pise04h.cloudfront.net/docs/issues_doc%2Fdevelopment%2FSDGCompass.pdf>
The SDG Compass explains how the SDGs affect business. This offers tools and knowledge to put sustainability at the heart of the strategy as well as key in CSR (Corporate Social Responsibility).

courses.description:
This is a compulsory three-unit and small-group student-orientated teaching (STOT) course for final year students, with teaching staff serving as supervisors, the emphasis will be on students’ participation and discussion. Student groups will choose a topic of their own interests, conduct research studies, present their findings and submit a report.

The course objectives include:
1. Arousing students’ interest in exploring contemporary local or global issues; 2. Sharpening research, problem-solving and thesis-writing skills; and
3. Enhancing ability in conducting group research projects and seminars which require a collective effort.
courses.course_syllabus:
As it is a STOT course, no specific subject contents will be taught in the class. Student groups will pick their own research topics and conduct formal research, present findings and prepare written report.

The course arrangements are as follows:

1. Pre-course registration and topic selection
2. Meetings and communication with respective class supervisors
3. Work out research plans
4. Literature review or background research
5. Setup milestones or schedule for the research processes
6. Conduct research via appropriate means (questionnaire, survey, interview, focus group, etc)
7. Confirm research findings, explore implications and limitations
8. Prepare oral presentations
9. Prepare written reports
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
2. Internal Course Review

1. Babbie, E. 2004. The Practice of Social Research. Thomason/Wadsworth.
2. Baker, T.L. 1999. Doing Social Research. 3rd ed. McGraw-Hill.
3. Chan, Y.K. et al. 1991. A Practical Guide to Sample Surveys. Hong Kong Statistical Society.
4. Dooley. D. 2001. Social Research Methods. 4th ed. Prentice Hall.

courses.subject: GEUC
courses.title: Social Enterprise and Innovation: Internship
courses.description:
This is an advanced experiential-learning course that will give students an opportunity to work directly for social enterprises under the guidance of their supervisors and professional mentors. Students would have opportunities to experience how the social enterprises help the underprivileged groups and gain hands-on business experience, which will strengthen their soft skills, help them implement the innovative business and promotional ideas in a practical way, and will greatly improve their understanding on the societal needs of the community, and the sustainable development directions and modes.

This course is designed to immerse students in the world of social enterprise. This course enables students to further develop career and apply leadership-ready skills in the operation of a social enterprise or social business. Students are encouraged to provide ideas to promote the designated social enterprise among the youth community, and they will also have an opportunity to undertake an internship in a real social enterprise setting.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For students of United College.
2. Pre-requisite: GEUC2103 or GEUC2213

SDG-SE #12 Responsible Consumption and Production
Internship
Service Learning Course
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Pre-Internship Preparation Activities

1. Pre-Internship orientation
1. Aim and objective of Internship
2. Nature, mission and business of the attached social enterprises
3. Roles and Responsibilities of students, supervisor and social enterprise supervisor
4. Concepts related to sustainable development goals
5. Workplace etiquette, work attitude and professional ethics at work
6. Practical arrangement
2. First meeting with the designated social enterprise
1. Meeting the social enterprise supervisor and self-introduction
2. Social enterprise and work place orientation
3. Working hours and practices arrangement
3. Creation of action plan
1. Preparing workplan to social enterprise supervisor
2. Workplan progress update process and timeline
3. Agreeing on measurement
4. Mutually agree on internship expectation and outcomes

1. During-Internship Learning Activities

1. Internship work, including action plan
1. Keeping work journal
2. Updating action plan periodically
3. Obtaining periodic feedback from social enterprise supervisor
2. Mid-term and final reports
1. Mid-term progress report to supervisor
2. Final report (draft version) to supervisor

1. Post-Internship Consolidation Activities

1. Final debriefing with the supervisor
1. Obtaining social enterprise evaluation report
2. Completing self-evaluation report
3. Meeting supervisor for debriefing
2. Final presentation
1. Presentation to supervisor and social enterprise supervisor
2. Final report submission with revision after final presentation
